awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PGE and Pb Systematics in Altered Abyssal Peridotites: Integrating Experiments with Natural Samples
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed work will test the hypothesis that changes in sulfide and metal alloy mineralogy during peridotite alteration will mobilize and fractionate the PGE, Re and Pb relative to their primary magmatic concentrations. Hydrothermal experiments will constrain the solubility of PGE, Re, Pb in mantle Ni-Fe-Ru-Re bearing sulfides and metal alloys as function of temperature and redox conditions, and evaluate PGE alloy exsolution and PGE-Re fractionation under low sulfur fugacity. The natural sample part of the study will constrain the distribution and fractionation of PGE, Re, Pb in sulfides, alloys and bulk rocks from well characterized abyssal peridotites, as function of redox, alteration, sulfide mineralization and primary composition (fertile versus depleted). Through integration of the experimental and natural sample data this work will constrain the fate of PGE, Re, Pb upon recycling of altered oceanic lithosphere and whether altered peridotites can develop, over time, highly heterogeneous 187Os/188Os and 186Os/188Os ratios between refractory (metal alloys) or mobile (sulfide) reservoirs. This project is a collaborative effort between 2 US institutions, and will promote transfer of technology and expertise on novel analytical techniques to a newly established geochemical facility at USC. Researchers will share a suite of state-of-the art instrumentation including FIB-SEM, FE-EMPA, FE-SEM, LA-ICPMS and synchrotron radiation micro-X-Ray fluorescence. All the data collected will be submitted to the PetDB and IEDA, and will be available to the public through a CIW-hosted data repository. A graduate student from USC will participate towards completion of his PhD studies.

Altered mantle rocks exposed at the seafloor (called "serpentinized abyssal peridotites") contain Ni-bearing metal phases associated with secondary plantinum-group element (PGE) sulfur-bearing minerals (sulfides) and PGE metal nuggets. PGEs have unique physical and chemical properties that are critical to many technological applications. Thus, they are often regarded as strategic metals in a wide range of industries including aerospace and fuel cell technology. The proposed research will significantly advance the currently limited understanding of the effects of high-temperature seawater alteration on the distribution of plantinum-group element sulfides hosted in abyssal peridotites. Moreover, abyssal peridotites provide an important record for understanding the composition and evolution of Earth?s mantle now and in the past. The proposed work is a collaborative experimental and natural sample investigation. Experimental data will define the thermodynamic properties of PGE minerals at conditions relevant to modern deep-sea volcanoes and assess critical details of PGE solubility mechanisms in Fe-Ni-Ru-Re sulfides/alloys at elevated temperature/-pressure conditions. The combined experimental results and natural sample data will lead to a fundamental new understanding on the effects of seawater alteration on the siderophile and chalcophile composition of altered peridotite and its effect on the Os and Pb isotope heterogeneity in the Earth?s mantle.

por.por_cntn:
Altered mantle rocks exposed at the seafloor (i.e serpentinized abyssal peridotites) contain Ni-bearing native metal phases in association with secondary plantinum-group element (PGE) sulfur-bearing minerals (sulfides) and native PGE metal nuggets. PGEs have unique physical and chemical properties that are critical to many technological applications. Thus, they are often regarded as strategic metals in a wide range of industries including aerospace and fuel cell technology. This project tested the hypothesis that changes in sulfide and metal alloy mineralogy during serpentinization can mobilize and fractionate the PGE, and Re relative to their primary magmatic concentrations. Through integration of the experimental and natural sample data we studied the fate of PGE and Re upon recycling of altered oceanic lithosphere into the Earth’s interior.

To determine the paragenetic relationships between PGE-Re-Os and Fe-Ni sulfides/alloys, we performed a series of hydrothermal experiments at 200-400 °C and 300-500 bar. Phase equilibrium relationships in the FeO-Fe2O3-NiO-H2S-H2O-HCl system were studied by reacting a seawater-salinity like aqueous solution with the assemblage of Fe-Ni oxides/sulfides and alloys (i.e., awaruite) under low sulfur fugacity conditions. We also conducted a series of thermodynamic calculations and phase equilibrium models to investigate the effect of abyssal peridotite alteration on the distribution of PGE and Re minerals. The broader stability of awaruite determined in our study suggests that it may be more commonly present in serpentinites than previously thought. Our experimental work further suggests that the presence of awaruite is an indicator that secondary PGE alloys and sulfides are present in the serpentine matrix. As PGE have low concentrations in the mantle these phases can be of low abundance and difficult to detect. We also analyzed abyssal peridotites from South West Indian Ridge and Salt Lake Crater, as well as, ophiolites from Santa Elena (Costa Rica). The detailed mineralogical and chemical analysis of these samples revealed the co-existance of Fe-Ni alloys with primary pentlandite (Fe-Ni sulfide) confirming the results of our experimental and theoretical studies.

The intriguing results of our recent studies indicate that hydrothermal alteration of abyssal peridotites likely plays a key role on the redistribution of platinum group minerals and the Re/Os and Pt/Os fractionation by decoupling the formation of secondary PGE-bearing sulfides from the precipitation of refractory metal alloys. These alloys could inherit the Os isotopic composition of the magmatic sulfides, and along with the possible precipitation of high Re/Os secondary sulfides due to seawater hydrothermal circulation. Subduction of altered peridotite is expected to contribute to the Os-isotope heterogeneities observed in the Earth’s mantle and may play a role in the subduction of Fe-Ni metal into the deep mantle. Fe-Ni-C-S liquids, now exsolved to assemblages that include Fe-Ni metal have recently discovered  in certain gem diamonds that are thought to have originated from the mantle transition zone.

Finally, a series of hydrothermal diamond anvil cell experiments was conducted at temperatures ranging from 500 to 950 °C and pressures of 0.5 to 30 kbar to investigate the solubility of Os, Ir and Re in Na-bearing alkaline and acidic aqueous solutions under oxidizing conditions. Experimental results indicate that Os, Re and Ir are more mobile in supercritical fluids that previously thought. Most importantly, we observed the formation of Os-O bearing species under acidic conditions which have direct implications for the mobility of Os in back-arc volcanic systems and the possible flux of Os in subductions zones. Experimental observations also revealed the enhanced formation of Na-bearing rhenium aqueous complexes in supercritical fluids. The inferred oxidation of Os to volatile OsO4 can potentially affect the Os-isotope composition of subducted oceanic crust and contribute to the Os isotope heterogeneity of the Earth's mantle. The Re-Os systematics associated with the dehydration of the subducted slab is expected to be affected by the enhanced solubility of rhenium in Na-bearing crustal fluids.

Our studies defined the thermodynamic properties of PGE minerals at conditions relevant to modern hydrothermal systems and assess the atomistic details of PGE solid-solution mechanisms in Fe-Ni-Ru-Re sulfides/alloys at elevated temperature/-pressure conditions. Results will be of broad interest to the experimental, geochemical and modeling community, as well as those working on PGE ore deposits.

 This project is collaborative effort between two US institutions and will enhance the analytical capabilities of the geochemistry facilities at USC by transferring technology and expertise from DTM. We developed analytical methods to analyze the PGE content of Fe-Ni metals and sulfides in abyssal peridotite samples. Experiments utilized synthetic CVD (chemical vapor deposition) ultrapure diamonds. These CVD technological advances have been pioneered at the Geophysical Laboratory. This projects invovled the participation of graduate (University of South Carolina), undergraduate (George Mason University) and high school students (Lick-Wilmerdinh High School). Opportunities for training and professional development were given to women and minority students.
